info.title: Creating Customized Virtual Machines Using virt-scenario
info.meta: Creating customized VM Guests using virt-scenario
Creating customized VM Guests using virt-scenario

listitem.para: When deploying multiple virtual machines (VM), they often serve a similar purpose. virt-scenario offers a way to quickly create a VM following a predefined scenario. As an option, you can create a secure VM or override certain default virt-scenario settings.

This article introduces the virt-scenario tool and describes available predefined scenarios for creating VMs. It outlines steps to create a VM suitable for a selected scenario, as well as available commands for the virt-scenario interactive shell.

It takes up to 30 minutes to understand virt-scenario and use it to create a basic VM. To learn and try additional topics, for example, how to override default values or use interactive commands, you need additional time.
virt-scenario requires KVM and libvirt virtualization environment configured and related daemons running.
Secure virtual machines are supported only by an AMD processor that supports AMD SEV or SEV-ES technology. For more information about SUSE and AMD SEV, refer to .

section.para: virt-scenario is a tool that helps you create virtual machines (VM) suitable for a specific scenario. It provides predefined profiles that include optimal settings for each scenario. You can override settings that are common to all profiles.

important.para: Although virt-scenario generally provides the best possible configuration for a specific scenario, this cannot be guaranteed because each environment may have specific requirements.

section.title: How does virt-scenario work?
section.para: Interactive virt-scenario script creates a libvirt XML configuration file for a VM based on the following:

listitem.para: selected basic profile
overridden values for common parameters
parameters that you specify interactively

section.para: After the configuration is validated, virt-scenario adjusts the VM Host Server system and creates the image file for the VM Guest. You can then operate the VM using standard libvirt commands.

listitem.para: Creating virtual machines is fast and simple. virt-scenario leaves all the virtualization complexity aside. You can focus on basic features only.
Fine-tuned profiles already offer optimal settings for specified scenarios. You do not have to search and copy them to each virtual machine of the same type, just use the same profile.
The override mechanism lets you specify other values than the profile's default for selected options. This way, you can customize virtual machines to your needs.

section.para: The virt-scenario command presents an interactive shell where you optionally specify configuration parameters and finally select the target scenario. Its welcome screen shows categories with available commands.

tip.para: Each command has a built-in description of its usage. Enter help COMMAND_NAME to view it on the screen.

warning.title: Unsafe force_sev option
warning.para: The force_sev option forces the extraction of the Platform Diffie-Hellman key (PDH) on the current AMD SEV system. The PDH file is used to negotiate a master secret between the SEV firmware and the external entities. This file must be stored in a secure place, and this option is only provided for testing purposes.

section.para: After you finish optional configuration steps, enter the name of one of the scenarios—computation, desktop or securevm. virt-scenario then compiles all the configuration, prepares the VM Host Server, and saves the libvirt XML of the new VM.

section.title: Overriding default scenario settings
section.para: On each run, virt-scenario reads settings for a new VM from the /etc/virt-scenario/virtscenario.yaml file. Change settings in this file to affect all VMs created by virt-scenario.

tip.para: Always backup /etc/virt-scenario/virtscenario.yaml before modifying it as incorrect parameters may lead to an invalid VM configuration.

section.para: To override settings for specific VMs only, copy /etc/virt-scenario/virtscenario.yaml to a different location and modify the settings that you need to override. On next virt-scenario run, specify the path to the new configuration file with the conf command, for example:

important.para: In the overriding virtscenario.yaml file, you need to include all available settings from the original virtscenario.yaml file, not only the modified settings.

warning.para: Never change section names in the /etc/virt-scenario/virtscenario.yaml file or its overriding copies.

section.para: The following is an example of /etc/virt-scenario/virtscenario.yaml:
section.screen: config: - path: /etc/virt-scenario - vm-config-store: ~/.local/virtscenario/ emulator: - emulator: /usr/bin/qemu-system-x86_64 input: - keyboard: virtio - mouse: virtio architecture: - arch: x86_64 STORAGE_DATA: # some options are only available with qcow2 format and # will be ignored in case of any other image format - disk_type: file - disk_cache: none - disk_target: vda - disk_bus: virtio - path: /var/livirt/images - format: qcow2 # host side: qemu-img creation options (-o), qemu-img --help - unit: G - capacity: 20 - cluster_size: 1024k - lazy_refcounts: on preallocation: full - preallocation: off - compression_type: zlib - encryption: off host_filesystem: - fmode: 644 - dmode: 755 - source_dir: /tmp - target_dir: /tmp/host

section.title: Specifying virt-scenario mode
section.para: By default, virt-scenario creates the libvirt XML configuration of the new guest and adjusts the VM Host Server. You can instruct virt-scenario to perform only part of the task. After entering the mode command, you can enter one of the following:

listitem.para: Creates only the libvirt XML configuration of the guest.
Prepares the VM Host Server system only.
Creates the guest configuration and prepares the host. This is the default mode.

abstract.para: You can use the following commands when configuring a new VM using the virt-scenario interactive shell.

tip.para: Each command has a built-in description of its usage. Enter help COMMAND_NAME to view it on the screen.

listitem.para: Loads hypervisor configuration.
Sets the hypervisor for which VMs are configured.
Lists available hypervisors.
Forces overwriting previous configuration.
Defines the name of the VM.
Specifies the number of virtual CPUs.
Specifies the memory size (in GiB).
Selects the machine type.
Selects the boot device.
Specifies the directory where to store the VM disk image.
Specifies the path to the custom virtscenario.yaml file.
Specifies the path to the CD/DVD installation media.
Creates a libvirt XML configuration and VM Host Server adjustments for the computation scenario.
Creates a libvirt XML configuration and VM Host Server adjustments for the desktop scenario.
Creates a libvirt XML configuration and VM Host Server adjustments for the secure VM scenario.

abstract.para: When creating a VM, you can specify one of the following scenarios:

listitem.para: Selecting this scenario results in an encrypted VM image with a high level of isolation and data security.
This scenario puts emphasis on the high performance of the resulting VM.
The result of this scenario is a VM suitable for running desktop applications.

section.para: After you created a VM using the virt-scenario interactive shell, use the virt-scenario-launch command to manage it. The command identifies VMs by their name as displayed by the --list option.
section.screen: # virt-scenario-launch --list Version: 2.1.2 Available VMs: ALP_OS desktop testing_vm SLE15_HPC
section.para: When the VM is identified, you can manage it with the following options.

listitem.para: Prints short descriptions of available options.
Starts the VM and prints security attestation information, for example:
listitem.screen: # virt-scenario-launch --start ALP_OS Connected to libvirtd socket; Version: 7001000 SEV(-ES) attestation passed! Validation successfull for domain ALPOS

listitem.para: Shows the status of the VM, for example:
listitem.screen: # virt-scenario-launch --status ALP_OS Version: 2.1.2 Connecting to libvirt qemu:///system ... Connected to libvirtd socket; Version: 7001000 Domain SLE15SP5HPC state: Shutoff

listitem.para: Shuts a VM down.
Forces a VM off.
